questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-day history of low-grade fever and progressive painful lumps in his right groin. The lumps have been discharging purulent fluid since the evening of the previous day. He had a shallow, painless lesion on his penis 3 weeks ago, but was too embarrassed to seek medical attention; it has resolved in the meantime. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). Examination of his groin shows multiple masses with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes the STI chancroid, which also presents with painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, single or multiple, painful genital ulcers covered with yellowish-greyish exudate would also be seen. Systemic manifestations such as fever are uncommon.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes the STI syphilis. Patients with primary syphilis also present with a painless, genital ulcer, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. The inguinal lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis differs in a number of ways, though: it is nonsuppurative, occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance, and is not accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). Moreover, the genital ulcer usually does not resolve within a week, but within 3–6 weeks without treatment.
Image Description:

A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Yersinia pestis is transmitted by fleas of small mammals (e.g., prairie dogs, squirrels, rats) and causes the plague, which may also present with tender, suppurative, regional lymphadenopathy (buboes) in the vicinity of the bite site (which is usually the leg), and high fever. However, bubonic plague is an extremely rare infection in the US, with an average of fewer than 7 cases reported annually. Also, patients do not present with genital ulcers.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 may also cause genital ulcers, fever, and tender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, usually multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers are present and inguinal lymphadenopathy is nonsuppurative.
Image Description:

The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.

These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

E) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes the STI granuloma inguinale, which may also present with painless lesions on the genitals initially. However, these lesions do not resolve spontaneously without treatment, as did the painless lesion on this patient's penis. Granuloma inguinale lesions are typically beefy-red, suppurative, bleed easily (due to their hypervascularity), and spread and destroy surrounding tissue until treated. Regional lymphadenopathy and fever are generally absent, making the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.

F) CORRECT:

The serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis are responsible for LGV, which is a sexually transmitted disease with an increasing incidence among men who have sex with men. Systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, chills, and/or myalgia can occur in addition to the local symptoms in the genital region. LGV is treated with doxycycline or macrolides such as erythromycin. Without antibiotic treatment, LGV can lead to chronic genital lymphedema, strictures in the anogenital tract, and infertility.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.
questions.hint: The history of a painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–4 weeks after the initial lesion has healed is in keeping with lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV).

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the physician with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Laboratory studies show a normal complete blood count; urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydatid of Morgagni torsion would also cause acute scrotal pain. But it does not cause dysuria and the ultrasound would not show increased vascularity, but rather an enlarged hydatid along with normal testes.

C) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced (!) perfusion to the affected testicle.

D) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

E) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse. But this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

F) INCORRECT:

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. She has not had fever, chills, or abdominal pain. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is sexually active with one male partner and they do not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. There is no uterine or cervical motion tenderness. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet mount preparation of vaginal smear can be used to detect flagellated protozoa characteristic of trichomoniasis and clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). These conditions can cause malodorous vaginal discharge but typically result in an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5). In addition, isolated cervicitis is not a typical manifestation of either of these conditions. A wet mount preparation is unreliable in diagnosing the most common infectious causes of cervicitis because these infections only cause the nonspecific finding of a high leukocyte number on the wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

The amine test (whiff test) is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause malodorous vaginal discharge. However, BV typically manifests with an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5) and a gray or milky rather than mucopurulent discharge. Isolated cervicitis makes BV highly unlikely. The amine test does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine analysis and culture would be the most appropriate initial step if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. This patient presents with cervicitis and does not report features of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain).

D) CORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred modality for diagnosing Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections, which are the most common causes of cervicitis. NAAT can also diagnose certain uncommon causes of acute cervicitis such as trichomoniasis. Patients with confirmed gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichomoniasis should also be screened for HIV and syphilis. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing is indicated during the initial prenatal visit (at approx. 10 weeks' gestation) in all patients < 25 years of age and in patients ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can manifest with vaginal discharge and a normal vaginal pH of 4.0–4.5. The discharge, however, is usually odorless and white, crumbly, and sticky rather than mucopurulent. In addition, features of inflammatory vaginitis (e.g., intense pruritus, vaginal burning, dyspareunia, vulvar and vaginal erythema) are typically present. Isolated cervicitis is not typical of vulvovaginal candidiasis. A KOH preparation does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.
questions.hint: An inflamed, friable cervix with a mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os in a sexually active patient suggests cervicitis.

questions.text: An endocervical swab is performed and nucleic acid amplification testing via polymerase chain reaction is conducted. It is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used in the case of chlamydial infection but the administration of doxycycline during pregnancy is contraindicated because intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in the teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring. Although cefoxitin is effective against N. gonorrhoeae, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need cefoxitin. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for N. gonorrhea infection. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhea and positive for C. trachomatis; ceftriaxone is not the first-line therapy for C. trachomatis.

C) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is very effective against C. trachomatis but the administration of fluoroquinolones is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation due to its potential to cause bone and cartilage damage in the fetus.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin is administered for chlamydial infections in which gonococcal infection is also suspected. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need ceftriaxone. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

E) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydial infection in nonpregnant patients but is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and tooth staining in the child. A single dose of oral azithromycin is the recommended first-line treatment for chlamydial infection in pregnant patients. Expedited partner testing and therapy are also recommended to avoid reinfection. Furthermore, patients and their sexual partners should abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days after treatment initiation.

F) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is a first-line treatment option in nonpregnant women who have an isolated chlamydial infection. Although this patient has tested positive for C. trachomatis, doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has cervicitis caused by C. trachomatis and should be treated with an antibiotic that is approved for use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 42 years. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and pelvic examinations show no abnormalities. An HIV test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count would be required if the patient had any signs of an infection, inflammation, or anemia but is not necessary in a young individual with no symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is highly sensitive and specific for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae and is the gold standard for screening for these infections. Genital chlamydia and gonorrhea may be asymptomatic but can cause complications if left untreated (e.g., infertility, pelvic inflammatory disease). Since this patient is sexually active, it is recommended that she be screened for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae, even though she is asymptomatic.

C) INCORRECT:

The current USPSTF recommendation for cervical cancer screening is a PAP smear every 3 years beginning at 21 years of age, regardless of the initiation of sexual activity. Cervical cancer is rare in women < 21 years of age. Moreover, detection of an abnormal PAP smear in this age group (e.g., due to a cervical infection/inflammation) may lead to overtreatment (e.g., surgical excision/laser/cryotherapy of the suspicious area of the cervix), which could adversely affect future childbearing and cause unnecessary anxiety. Since this patient is 17 years of age, a PAP smear is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

In the US, vaccination against HPV is part of the routine immunization schedule. The vaccine can be administered from 9–26 years of age, but should ideally be administered between 11–12 years of age and preferably before any sexual contact to be most effective. Since the immunizations of this 17-year-old patient are up-to-date, it is highly likely that she has already received the vaccination against HPV.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) infections may be asymptomatic and this patient is at risk because of her unprotected sexual activity. However, the CDC generally reserves HSV-2 screening for high-risk groups, including HIV-positive patients, men who have sex with men, and patients recently diagnosed with an STI, none of which applies to this patient.
questions.hint: The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends chlamydia and gonorrhea screening in sexually active women < 25 years of age and in older women with risk factors for STIs.

questions.text: A previously healthy 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever and fluid release from painful lumps in the right groin. He had an atraumatic ulceration of the penis about 1 month ago that was not painful and resolved on its own within 1 week. He works at an animal shelter for abandoned pets. He is sexually active with multiple male partners and does not use condoms. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Examination of the groin shows numerous, tender nodules with purulent discharge. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infection with Bartonella henselae causes cat scratch disease (CSD), which can manifest with fever, general malaise, and tender, suppurative lymphadenopathy. This patient's history of working at an animal shelter puts him at risk for exposure to Bartonella henselae. However, CSD typically manifests with papules and/or pustules at the cutaneous site of inoculation, which is most commonly in the limbs. This patient's penile lesion and sexual history make a different causative pathogen more likely.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

B) INCORRECT:

Treponema pallidum causes syphilis. Primary syphilis manifests with a painless, genital ulcer (chancre) and inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient's lesions, the inguinal lymphadenopathy associated with syphilis is nonsuppurative, occurs within a week of the chancre's appearance, and is not accompanied by systemic symptoms (e.g., fever). Moreover, the genital ulcer usually resolves within 3–6 weeks without treatment (rather than 1 week).
Image Description:

A superficial ulcer with indurated borders is visible on the glans penis.

This finding is consistent with primary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2) can cause genital ulcers, fever, and tender, inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, HSV-2 usually causes multiple, grouped, painful genital ulcers and nonsuppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. In contrast to this patient's initial ulcer, these lesions do not spontaneously resolve.
Image Description:

The entire genital area appears erythematous with an inflamed vaginal vestibule and urinary meatus. Solitary erythematous papules are visible inside the labia minora. Furthermore, there are white purulent lesions in the vaginal introitus.

These findings are consistent with genital herpes, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

D) CORRECT:

The serotypes L1, L2, and L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis cause lymphogranuloma venereum, the incidence of which is increased in men who have sex with men. Further manifestations include systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, chills, and/or myalgia. Lymphogranuloma venereum is treated with doxycycline or macrolides such as erythromycin. Without antibiotic treatment, lymphogranuloma venereum can cause chronic genital lymphedema, strictures in the anogenital tract, and/or infertility.
Image Description:

Bilateral enlargement of the inguinal lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament is visible (groove sign).

The groove sign is characteristic of lymphogranuloma venereum, which is caused by acute Chlamydia trachomatis infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid, which causes painful, suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy. However, unlike this patient, who has a history of a self-resolving, painless genital ulcer, chancroid causes painful genital ulcers with yellow-gray exudates. Systemic manifestations, such as fever, are uncommon.
Image Description:

There is an ulcer with an erythematous margin on the corona of the glans penis. This is a characteristic chancroid lesion, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Klebsiella granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale, which can initially manifest with painless, suppurative genital lesions. However, these lesions are typically beefy-red, bleed easily (due to their hypervascularity), spread and destroy surrounding tissue, and do not resolve spontaneously without treatment. Regional lymphadenopathy and fever are generally absent, making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Perianal region of a female patient with Klebsiella granulomatis infection

Multiple confluent, partially ulcerated papules are visible.

Diagnosis was confirmed via visualization of darkly staining Donovan bodies in biopsy crush preparations.
questions.hint: A painless penile lesion followed by suppurative lymphadenopathy 2–4 weeks after the initial lesion has healed is consistent with a diagnosis of lymphogranuloma venereum.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 1-week-history of painful urination and urinary frequency. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. She is sexually active with her boyfriend. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F). There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase. A Gram stain does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans is the yeast responsible for candidal vulvovaginitis, which can also present with dysuria, as seen in this patient. However, microscopic examination would typically show branching pseudohyphae with budding yeasts, unlike the findings here. Moreover, vulvovaginal candidiasis typically presents with a thick cottage cheese-like vaginal discharge, which this patient does not have.
Image Description:

Vaginal wet mount after potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation (microscopy) that shows Candida albicans forming multiple pseudohyphae (thin filamentous structures; examples indicated by blue overlay).

The prominent grey and white circles are optical artifacts.

White circles: examples of budding yeast

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the bacterium that causes gonorrhea, which can also manifest with urethritis and vulvovaginitis, as seen in this patient. However, Gram stain would typically show gram-negative diplococci, as opposed to the findings here. While gonorrhea may be asymptomatic, it often manifests with purulent, creamy vaginal discharge.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of an urethral smear specimen (Gram stain with fuchsin counterstain; high magnification)

The smear shows an abundance of neutrophils recognizable by their typical segmented nuclei and accumulations of diplococci, in the intracellular (within neutrophils; examples indicated by white arrowheads in magnification) and extracellular space (examples indicated by black arrowheads).

This microscopic finding is characteristic of acute gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Diagnosis must be confirmed by cultural isolation and identification of the pathogens.

C) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of urinary tract infections (UTI) in adults. UTI caused by E. coli can also present with dysuria, urinary frequency, and a positive leukocyte esterase test, as seen here. However, gram stain of the urine would show gram-negative rods, as opposed to the findings here.

D) INCORRECT:

Gardnerella vaginalis is a gram-variable rod that causes bacterial vaginosis. Sexual intercourse is the primary risk factor for bacterial vaginosis although it is not considered an STI. Microscopic examination would show clue cells, as opposed to this patient's findings. Moreover, bacterial vaginosis is typically painless and may present with a gray or milky vaginal discharge with a fishy odor that this patient does not have.

E) CORRECT:

This patient likely has Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Although most cases are asymptomatic, patients can present with urethritis and/or vulvovaginitis, as seen here. Chlamydiae do not gram stain well because they are obligate intracellular bacteria that lack muramic acid in their cell wall. In the diagnosis of chlamydia infection, Giemsa stain or fluorescent antibody stain can be used to identify reticulate bodies (i.e., cytoplasmic inclusions.) PCR (nucleic acid amplification) is the gold standard diagnostic test for chlamydiae.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of cells in McCoy cell culture (unknown magnification)

Cells infected with Chlamydia trachomatis (black arrows) show inclusion bodies (reticulate bodies, here in brown) under the microscope.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular bacteria that require cell culture, rather than growth medium, to grow. This characteristic is especially important for determining the best antibiotic for treatment.

F) INCORRECT:

Trichomonas vaginalis is the causative organism of Trichomonas vaginitis, a sexually transmitted disease that typically presents with dysuria. However, microscopic examination would show motile flagellated protozoa, as opposed to the findings here. Moreover, Trichomonas vaginitis classically presents with a yellow-green, foul-smelling vaginal discharge, which this patient lacks.
Image Description:

Phase contrast photomicrograph of vaginal discharge (high magnification)

These parasites with flagella (blue overlay) are Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative pathogen of trichomonal vaginitis.

In the center, two squamous epithelial cells can be seen.
questions.hint: This sexually active patient presents with features of urethritis and vulvovaginitis (painful urination, positive leukocyte esterase) and a negative urine Gram stain. She likely has an infection with an organism that lacks muramic acid in the cell wall.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, headache, myalgia, photophobia, and a nonproductive cough for 2 days. Three weeks ago, she received a parrot as a birthday present. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Her leukocyte count is 8000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse patchy infiltrates that are most prominent in the lower lobes. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Coxiella burnetii is an obligate intracellular organism that causes Q fever, a zoonosis that presents with flu-like symptoms, high-grade fever, and other features of atypical pneumonia. It is also a common cause of culture-negative endocarditis. However, it is transmitted by the inhalation of spores from contaminated feces, urine, milk, and birth products of sheep and cattle. Q fever is not associated with exposure to parrots (or birds in general).

B) CORRECT:

Chlamydia psittaci is the organism that causes psittacosis (“parrot fever”), a rare zoonotic disease that causes atypical pneumonia and is transmitted via feces and dander of infected birds. Infected individuals typically have a history of close contact with birds and present with fever, chills, nonproductive cough, and headaches, as seen in this patient. Bird owners, pet shop employees, veterinarians, and poultry workers are at increased risk of this condition. Psittacosis is a notifiable disease in the United States.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that is most commonly transmitted by inhaling dust contaminated with the feces of infected birds (most commonly pigeons). Cryptococcus may manifest with pulmonary symptoms (pulmonary cryptococcosis), but can also cause meningitis and encephalitis through hematogenous spread to the meninges. However, infection is extremely rare in healthy individuals without HIV infection, making a different organism more likely for this patient's symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Leptospira interrogans is the organism that causes leptospirosis, a zoonosis with variable presentation ranging from mild, flu-like symptoms to severe multiorgan dysfunction (e.g., Weil disease, pulmonary hemorrhage). However, L. interrogans is transmitted via the urine of infected rodents, dogs, cattle, and other mammals. It is not associated with exposure to parrots (or birds in general).

E) INCORRECT:

Babesia microti, the causative organism of babesiosis, typically causes mild flu-like symptoms, but severe infection can lead to hemolytic anemia, DIC, ARDS, and death. Babesia spp are transmitted by Ixodes scapularis ticks, but not by parrots (or birds in general).

Lyme disease and babesiosis share the same tick vector (Ixodes), leading to the possibility of coinfection.

F) INCORRECT:

Francisella tularensis causes tularemia, a highly infectious zoonosis that is transmitted by rodents, ticks, and deer flies. Pulmonary tularemia classically presents with high fever, cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Tularemia is not transmitted by parrots, making this unlikely in this patient.
questions.hint: In a patient with recent exposure to a parrot, flu-like symptoms (fever, headache, myalgia) and a nonproductive cough should raise suspicion for the disease commonly known as “parrot fever”.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of low-grade fever, dry cough, and shortness of breath. His symptoms began 6 days ago while he was on vacation in Thailand where he went to an urgent care clinic and was started on cefuroxime. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at bilateral lung bases. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse patchy infiltrates. Sputum analysis shows numerous neutrophils but no organisms. Giemsa stain shows epithelial cells with cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. This patient's condition did not improve after the initial treatment because of which of the following properties of the most likely causal pathogen?

choices.text: Lack of peptidoglycan in cell wall
Rapid alteration of drug binding sites

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antigenic variation of adhesive pili is a virulence factor of Neisseria gonorrhea, which mediates binding to target cells and facilitates evasion of the host immune system. However, N. gonorrhoeae causes genitourinary infections and neonatal conjunctivitis, not pneumonia. Furthermore, sputum analysis would most likely show gram-negative bacteria, and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Chlamydophila pneumoniae is an obligate intracellular bacterium (only visible as intracellular inclusion bodies) that causes upper and lower respiratory tract infections, including atypical pneumonia. Like other Chlamydia spp., it lacks peptidoglycans in its cell wall and is therefore resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., cefuroxime), which act by inhibiting peptidoglycan crosslinking. First-line treatment would be with a macrolide antibiotic, which inhibits bacterial protein synthesis (e.g., erythromycin, azithromycin).

C) INCORRECT:

Polysaccharide capsules are a virulence factor utilized by several bacteria, some of which are common pathogens in community-acquired pneumonia, e.g., Streptococcus pneumoniae and Klebsiella pneumoniae. However, these microbes more commonly cause lobar pneumonia, which typically manifests acutely with high fever, malaise, productive cough, and opacity restricted to one pulmonary lobe on x-ray. Furthermore, sputum analysis would not show cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain, as encapsulated bacteria are extracellular.

D) INCORRECT:

Formation of biofilms is a feature of several pathogens, including Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Haemophilus influenzae. As opposed to P. aeruginosa, which typically causes nosocomial pneumonia, H. influenzae can cause community-acquired lobar pneumonia. However, lobar pneumonia would present more acutely than the symptoms observed in this patient, with malaise, high fever, productive cough, and opacity restricted to one pulmonary lobe on x-ray. Furthermore, sputum analysis would likely show gram-negative bacteria, and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Production of beta-lactamase enzymes, which hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins), is a feature of extended-spectrum beta-lactamase-producing bacteria (ESBL). ESBL are associated with nosocomial pneumonia and are very unlikely to cause community-acquired pneumonia. Furthermore, sputum analysis would most likely show gram-negative bacteria, and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain would not be expected.

F) INCORRECT:

Rapid alteration of drug binding sites, e.g., mutations in transpeptidase that confer resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics (such as cefuroxime) or changes in DNA gyrase that result in resistance to fluoroquinolones, is a common mechanism of resistance. Although this patient had no clinical response to cefuroxime, this is most likely due to a different feature of the causal organism, not a rapid alteration of the drug target.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (low-grade fever, dry cough, shortness of breath, and diffuse patchy infiltrates on x-ray) is consistent with interstitial (atypical) pneumonia. The cytoplasmic inclusion bodies on Giemsa stain are indicative of Chlamydophila pneumoniae as the responsible pathogen.

questions.text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of nasal discharge and cough. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Two weeks ago, his mother noticed a “thick yellow-green discharge” from his left eye that was treated at home with teabag compressions. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The patient appears irritable. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows short, repetitive episodes of cough with brief inspirations between each cough. Bilateral, diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is mild swelling of the left eyelid. Polymerase chain reaction tests of nasopharyngeal and ocular secretions are positive for the same pathogen. Which of the following is the most likely causal microorganism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which can cause neonatal conjunctivitis with thick, purulent ocular discharge and pronounced eyelid swelling, is transmitted perinatally during vaginal delivery and can be screened for during prenatal care (prenatal gonorrhea screening). However, gonococcal conjunctivitis typically manifests in newborns 2–7 days after delivery, whereas this patient's presentation began after 2 weeks. In addition to neonatal conjunctivitis, N. gonorrhea infection can cause disseminated gonococcal infection and septic arthritis, but not pneumonia.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

B) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection can cause rhinorrhea, bronchiolitis, and, occasionally, afebrile pneumonia during infancy or the late neonatal period. Both bronchiolitis and pneumonia cause cough, hypoxemia, and crackles on auscultation. Conjunctival injection may be present in patients with RSV infection, as seen here. However, RSV does not cause purulent conjunctivitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Parainfluenza virus type 1 typically causes croup, which can manifest with nasal congestion, a cough (classically a “barking seal” cough), and features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia). Patients may be afebrile or only have a low-grade fever during the prodromal phase. However, croup is characterized by hoarseness and inspiratory stridor, rather than crackles, and it more commonly affects children 6 months to 3 years of age. Moreover, this patient's history of purulent conjunctivitis suggests a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause pneumonia during infancy and the late neonatal period. However, pneumococcal pneumonia typically has a more severe presentation with high fever, whereas this neonate has afebrile pneumonia. Moreover, S. pneumoniae is a common cause of conjunctivitis in older children and young adults (pneumococcal conjunctivitis), but not in neonates.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus; GBS) infection in neonates can manifest as pneumonia, and this patient's mother most likely did not receive prenatal screening for GBS colonization. However, neonatal pneumonia due to GBS would manifest within the first 6 days of life (early-onset GBS infection), whereas the pneumonia in this newborn manifested at 4 weeks of life. Late-onset GBS infection, which occurs 1–12 weeks after birth, usually manifests with neonatal meningitis or neonatal sepsis, but not pneumonia. Moreover, GBS is a rare cause of neonatal conjunctivitis.

F) CORRECT:

This newborn has Chlamydia trachomatis infection that likely was transmitted during delivery and is manifesting as neonatal conjunctivitis and afebrile pneumonia syndrome. Neonatal conjunctivitis due to C. trachomatis typically manifests 5–14 days after birth and likely explains this patient's mucopurulent eye discharge and swelling. Chlamydial pneumonia, which usually manifests 4–12 weeks after birth can be accompanied by neonatal conjunctivitis and is characterized by a staccato cough with or without low-grade fever and features of interstitial pneumonia on chest x-ray. C. trachomatis infection is treated with macrolide antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin). Prenatal screening for C. trachomatis infection is indicated for pregnant women < 25 years of age.

G) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2), which can be transmitted during vaginal delivery (if the mother has active genital herpes), would cause neonatal keratoconjunctivitis and, in the case of disseminated disease, pneumonia. However, HSV-induced keratoconjunctivitis is associated with vesicles and nonpurulent watery discharge, not purulent discharge. Moreover, disseminated HSV infection usually occurs within a few days of the onset of mucocutaneous or ophthalmological disease; pulmonary involvement 2 weeks after the onset of ophthalmological disease indicates a different diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection (pertussis) can result in nasal discharge and cough without fever during the catarrhal stage, which may be brief in young infants. The catarrhal stage would be followed by paroxysms of a staccato cough with hypoxemia, as seen here (paroxysmal stage). Young infants are also at higher risk of developing complications of pertussis, such as pneumonia, and a lack of prenatal care (e.g., third trimester Tdap immunization) increases the risk of pertussis. However, B. pertussis does not cause neonatal conjunctivitis, so it is not the most likely causal organism.
questions.hint: This patient developed neonatal conjunctivitis and now presents with nasal congestion and features of pneumonia (tachypnea, hypoxemia, cough, and crackles on auscultation). Eosinophilia on a complete blood count is a relatively specific diagnostic clue for this newborn's condition, which could most likely have been prevented with adequate prenatal care.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with a 6-week history of mild, chronic injection and mild mucus discharge in both eyes. She also reports mild dysuria and vaginal discharge. She has no eye pain, photophobia, or decreased vision.
Infection with which one of the following organisms is likely to have caused the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Other pathogens associated with bacterial conjunctivitis, including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species, and Haemophilus influenzae, usually cause a purulent discharge and would be less likely to cause concurrent urethral symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes a hyperacute conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge and should be considered an ophthalmologic emergency because it can lead to blindness. Concomitant urethral symptoms are common. This infection would be expected to progress more rapidly and with greater severity than seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Mycoplasma genitalium is a well-recognized cause of urethritis, particularly in men, and has been reported to cause conjunctivitis. By contrast, Mycoplasma pneumoniae primarily causes respiratory illness; although this organism is a cause of conjunctivitis, one would not typically expect urinary symptoms and vaginal discharge with this infection.

D) CORRECT:

A patient who reports mild chronic bilateral conjunctivitis and pain with urination most likely has chlamydial conjunctivitis resulting from autoinoculation.

Chlamydia trachomatis, a common cause of chronic indolent conjunctivitis, is associated with injection, mucus discharge, preauricular lymph-node enlargement, follicles on the inferior tarsal conjunctiva, and a history of urethritis, cervicitis, or vaginitis. C. trachomatis infections are diagnosed using conjunctival culture, DNA probe, or microscopic examination. C. trachomatis infections are generally treated with oral antibiotics, preferably azithromycin or doxycycline. Topical antibiotic ointments, such as erythromycin or tetracycline, can be used as adjunctive therapy.

Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes that cause urethritis and chronic conjunctivitis are different than the ones that cause endemic trachoma. Endemic trachoma is seen in resource-limited settings and is rare outside the developing world.

In a patient with conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis, the diagnosis of reactive arthritis should be entertained. In this particular case, the patient did not report arthritis or photophobia, which would be a sign of concomitant uveitis.

Key learning point: A patient with mild chronic conjunctivitis and pain with urination most likely has a diagnosis of chlamydial conjunctivitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Other pathogens associated with bacterial conjunctivitis, including Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus species, and Haemophilus influenzae, usually cause a purulent discharge and would be less likely to cause concurrent urethral symptoms.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents with a 10-day history of dysuria. He denies fevers or chills, back pain, abdominal pain, testicular pain, or urethral discharge. He reports having vaginal intercourse with multiple partners during the past 6 months and did not use condoms.
A Gram stain of a urine specimen reveals >20 white cells per oil immersion field. There are no intracellular organisms or mobile parasites identified.
Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Chlamydia and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is the treatment of choice for syphilis. Syphilis does not typically manifest as urethritis, but coinfections are common.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an alternative treatment for granuloma inguinale, a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely causes of uncomplicated, purulent urethritis among sexually active men are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis infection. A nucleic acid amplification test can help determine the causative organism. If chlamydial urethritis is confirmed, then the recommended treatment is doxycycline 100 mg twice daily by mouth for 7 days. Azithromycin 1 gram by mouth as a single dose is an alternative, but doxycycline is preferred because it is more effective.

Key learning point: The treatment of choice for chlamydial and other nongonococcal urethritis is doxycycline.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for gonorrhea.

E) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomonas infection and is not recommended as first-line treatment for nongonococcal urethritis.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 24-year-old man presents with a one-week history of rectal pain, scant rectal bleeding, and discharge with fecal urgency. He reports no fevers or other symptoms. He has no known chronic medical problems, and his only medication is tenofovir disoproxil fumarate-emtricitabine for HIV preexposure prophylaxis. He has receptive anal sex with men without condoms.
On physical examination, he has diffuse rectal tenderness but no masses. A rectal nucleic acid amplification test is negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae but positive for Chlamydia trachomatis. Serologic tests for HIV, syphilis, and hepatitis C virus are negative, as are stool cultures and stool ova and parasite examinations.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate?

choices.text: Prescribe mesalamine 1 gram by rectum daily
Provide a single dose of ceftriaxone 500 mg by intramuscular injection
Provide a single dose of azithromycin 1 gram by mouth
Prescribe doxycycline 100 mg twice daily by mouth for 21 days

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mesalamine suppositories may improve inflammatory bowel disease, but they would not be beneficial for rectal chlamydia infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is used to treat gonorrhea and would not address this patient’s chlamydia infection.

C) INCORRECT:

A single dose of azithromycin would not adequately treat LGV and is no longer recommended as a first-line treatment for urogenital chlamydia infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Colonoscopy with biopsy is not recommended as an initial step, although it may be helpful to investigate for other causes if the patient’s symptoms do not improve with treatment for LGV.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has acute proctitis. Although inflammatory bowel disease could cause this clinical picture, infectious causes are more likely in a patient who engages in receptive anal sex without condoms. Infectious causes of proctitis include gonorrhea, syphilis, chlamydia, and herpes simplex virus. Enteric pathogens, such as Shigella and Entamoeba histolytica, can also cause proctocolitis and can be sexually transmitted.

Most mild or asymptomatic urogenital infections due to Chlamydia trachomatis are caused by serovars A through K. However, severe or invasive infections — particularly proctitis — raise concern for lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV), which is caused by C. trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3. Without appropriate treatment, LGV can progress and cause fistulae, strictures, and severe painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo). Confirmatory testing for LGV is not widely available, so in the context of a compatible clinical picture and nucleic acid amplification testing showing C. trachomatis, treatment for LGV is warranted. Recommended treatment consists of doxycycline 100 mg twice daily by mouth for 21 days.

Key learning point: Acute proctitis with a positive test for Chlamydia trachomatis should raise concern for lymphogranuloma venereum and be treated with a 21-day course of doxycycline.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the office with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3.  An endocervical swab is performed and nucleic acid amplification testing via polymerase chain reaction is conducted. It is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used in the case of chlamydial infection but the administration of doxycycline during pregnancy is contraindicated because intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in the teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring. Although cefoxitin is effective against N. gonorrhoeae, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need cefoxitin. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is very effective against C. trachomatis but the administration of fluoroquinolones is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation due to its potential to cause bone and cartilage damage in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

The combination of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin is administered for chlamydial infections in which gonococcal infection is also suspected. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need ceftriaxone. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

D) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydial infection in nonpregnant patients but is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and tooth staining in the child. A single dose of oral azithromycin is the recommended first-line treatment for chlamydial infection in pregnant patients. Expedited partner testing and therapy are also recommended to avoid reinfection. Furthermore, patients and their sexual partners should abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days after treatment initiation.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is a first-line treatment option in nonpregnant women who have an isolated chlamydial infection. Although this patient has tested positive for C. trachomatis, doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has cervicitis caused by C. trachomatis and should be treated with an antibiotic that is approved for use in pregnant patients.
