questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to the office with right-sided, dull, throbbing scrotal pain for 12 hours. He has also had a burning sensation on urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not had urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. Physical examination shows a tender right testicle; lifting it provides relief. The penis appears normal, with no discharge at the meatus. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. A Gram stain of a urethral swab shows polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound shows increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

B) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced (!) perfusion to the affected testicle.

C) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

D) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse. But this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

E) INCORRECT:

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.

questions.text:
A 3-week-old girl is brought to the Emergency Department with a one-week history of mild cough, nasal congestion, and occasional difficulty breathing. She was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. The mother recalls vaginal discharge late in pregnancy and notes the infant developed mild bilateral eye discharge around two weeks of age that resolved spontaneously. Auscultation reveals sparse crackles but no wheezing (see lab results and report).


Respiratory rate
60/min


Temperature
37.2°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
15 x 10⁹/L
9.1-30.1 x 10⁹/L


Eosinophils
5 %
1 - 4 %



Chest X-ray: Hyperinflation and bilateral interstitial infiltrates
Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection presents with paroxysmal coughing spells and whooping, which are absent here. Pertussis is associated with lymphocytosis, not eosinophilia. The chest X-ray findings and maternal history suggest a different pathogen, making pertussis unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Chlamydial pneumonia in infants is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically acquired during delivery from an infected maternal genital tract. The condition often follows a sequence where neonatal conjunctivitis resolves before respiratory symptoms develop, usually between 2 and 12 weeks of age. Symptoms include a staccato cough, mild respiratory distress, and absence of significant fever. Chest X-ray findings often show hyperinflation and bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Laboratory findings may include mild eosinophilia, consistent with the atypical pneumonic process of Chlamydia trachomatis.

Key learning point: Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of neonatal conjunctivitis and can lead to pneumonia characterized by a staccato cough and interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray.

C) INCORRECT:

Group B streptococcal pneumonia typically presents within the first week of life with severe symptoms and lobar consolidation on imaging. The infant's mild symptoms, age, and chest X-ray findings of hyperinflation and interstitial infiltrates do not align with this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in infants typically presents with cough, nasal congestion, and wheezing. However, it does not involve conjunctivitis or maternal genital infection. The absence of significant wheezing and fever, along with the radiographic findings, makes RSV less likely.

questions.text:
A 10-week-old infant is brought to the clinic with a 1-week history of an intermittent cough described as staccato-like bursts. The mother reports mild eye discharge 3 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. The infant is afebrile with mildly increased work of breathing. Bilateral crackles are heard on auscultation. A complete blood count reveals peripheral eosinophilia.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) bronchiolitis commonly causes lower respiratory tract infections in infants, but typically presents with a dry or wheezy cough and wheezing, not a staccato-like cough. Peripheral eosinophilia is atypical for RSV, which is a viral infection. The history of mild eye discharge suggests conjunctival involvement, more consistent with atypical pathogens.

B) CORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia typically occurs in infants aged 4 to 12 weeks and presents with a staccato cough, mild respiratory distress, and absence of fever. The history of mild eye discharge suggests prior conjunctivitis, indicating perinatal transmission from an infected maternal birth canal. Bilateral crackles on auscultation and peripheral eosinophilia are characteristic findings. This combination of age-specific presentation, non-febrile staccato cough, preceding conjunctivitis, and eosinophilia aligns with Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia.

Key learning point: Chlamydia trachomatis pneumonia in infants is characterized by staccato cough, preceding conjunctivitis, and eosinophilia, typically occurring in infants aged 4-12 weeks.

C) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae pneumonia usually presents with high fever, cough, and lobar consolidation, along with a neutrophilic response. The infant's afebrile status, staccato-like cough, bilateral crackles, and peripheral eosinophilia are not typical for this bacterial pneumonia. The history of mild eye discharge suggests an atypical infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Bordetella pertussis infection is known for paroxysmal cough episodes with inspiratory 'whoop' or post-tussive vomiting and marked lymphocytosis. The staccato-like cough and peripheral eosinophilia in this infant are not characteristic of pertussis. The previous mild eye discharge is not commonly associated with pertussis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of fever, headache, myalgia, photophobia, and a nonproductive cough. She reports that three weeks ago, she received a parrot as a birthday present. Her temperature is 38.5°C. Pulmonary examination reveals crackles at both lung bases. Her white blood cell count is 8.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5). A chest x-ray shows diffuse patchy infiltrates, most prominent in the lower lobes. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Francisella tularensis causes tularemia, a highly infectious zoonosis that is transmitted by rodents, ticks, and deer flies. Pulmonary tularemia classically presents with high fever, cough, chest pain, and shortness of breath. Tularemia is not transmitted by parrots, making this unlikely in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Chlamydia psittaci is the organism that causes psittacosis (“parrot fever”), a rare zoonotic disease that causes atypical pneumonia and is transmitted via feces and dander of infected birds. Infected individuals typically have a history of close contact with birds and present with fever, chills, nonproductive cough, and headaches, as seen in this patient. Bird owners, pet shop employees, veterinarians, and poultry workers are at increased risk of this condition. Psittacosis is a notifiable disease in the United States.

Key learning point: Psittacosis, an atypical pneumonia associated with bird exposure, is caused by Chlamydia psittaci and is transmitted via inhalation of feces or dander from infected birds.

C) INCORRECT:

Coxiella burnetii is an obligate intracellular organism that causes Q fever, a zoonosis that presents with flu-like symptoms, high-grade fever, and other features of atypical pneumonia. It is also a common cause of culture-negative endocarditis. However, it is transmitted by the inhalation of spores from contaminated feces, urine, milk, and birth products of sheep and cattle. Q fever is not associated with exposure to parrots (or birds in general).

D) INCORRECT:

Leptospira interrogans is the organism that causes leptospirosis, a zoonosis with variable presentation ranging from mild, flu-like symptoms to severe multiorgan dysfunction (e.g., Weil disease, pulmonary hemorrhage). However, L. interrogans is transmitted via the urine of infected rodents, dogs, cattle, and other mammals. It is not associated with exposure to parrots (or birds in general).

E) INCORRECT:

Cryptococcus neoformans is an encapsulated yeast that is most commonly transmitted by inhaling dust contaminated with the feces of infected birds (most commonly pigeons). Cryptococcus may manifest with pulmonary symptoms (pulmonary cryptococcosis), but can also cause meningitis and encephalitis through hematogenous spread to the meninges. However, infection is extremely rare in healthy individuals without HIV infection, making a different organism more likely for this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: In a patient with recent exposure to a parrot, flu-like symptoms (fever, headache, myalgia) and a nonproductive cough should raise suspicion for the disease commonly known as “parrot fever”.

questions.text: You are seeing a 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation who presents with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation was unremarkable. On pelvic examination, her cervix appears inflamed and friable, with a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. Vaginal pH is 4.3. An endocervical swab is sent for nucleic acid amplification testing, which is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used in the case of chlamydial infection but the administration of doxycycline during pregnancy is contraindicated because intake may lead to bone damage and deposits in the teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring. Although cefoxitin is effective against N. gonorrhoeae, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need cefoxitin. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.

B) CORRECT:

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydial infection in nonpregnant patients but is contraindicated during pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and tooth staining in the child. A single dose of oral azithromycin is the recommended first-line treatment for chlamydial infection in pregnant patients. Expedited partner testing and therapy are also recommended to avoid reinfection. Furthermore, patients and their sexual partners should abstain from sexual intercourse for seven days after treatment initiation.

Key learning point: Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for Chlamydia trachomatis infection during pregnancy because doxycycline and fluoroquinolones are contraindicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline is a first-line treatment option in nonpregnant women who have an isolated chlamydial infection. Although this patient has tested positive for C. trachomatis, doxycycline is contraindicated in pregnancy because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) of the offspring.

D) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is very effective against C. trachomatis but the administration of fluoroquinolones is contraindicated during pregnancy and lactation due to its potential to cause bone and cartilage damage in the fetus.

E) INCORRECT:

The combination of intramuscular ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin is administered for chlamydial infections in which gonococcal infection is also suspected. However, this patient has tested negative for N. gonorrhoeae and therefore does not need ceftriaxone. Given the high sensitivity (∼ 99%) of nucleic acid amplification testing for the detection of gonorrhea, a negative test result virtually rules out gonococcal infection.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has cervicitis caused by C. trachomatis and should be treated with an antibiotic that is approved for use in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge that began 2 days ago. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 39°C. On pelvic examination, there is pain with movement of the cervix and mucopurulent cervical discharge. Gram stain of the discharge does not show any organisms, but Giemsa stain reveals intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which one of the following complications is she at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Purulent arthritis is a complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While N. gonorrhoeae is a relatively common cause of PID, this pathogen is visible on Gram stain and does not show on Giemsa stain (unlike this patient's findings). A complication of Chlamydia trachomatis infection (which this patient has) is reactive arthritis, not purulent arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilatation is associated with tertiary syphilis, which results from infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients with PID may have concomitant syphilis. However, the initial manifestations of syphilis are chancre and lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis), which are not present in this patient. Additionally, infection with Treponema pallidum does not typically cause cervical tenderness or discharge.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is more strongly associated with HPV infection rather than Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Unprotected intercourse, which most likely caused PID in this patient, increases the risk of HPV infection. Cervical cancer rates are higher in women who have had PID than in the general population, but this is most likely due to increased rates of HPV infection rather than the effect of PID.

D) INCORRECT:

The etiology of endometriosis is thought to be multifactorial. Retrograde menstruation, lymphogenic and hematogenic dissemination of endometrial cells, changes in immunity and endocrine signaling, and genetic factors all play a role in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Chlamydial infection and PID are not known to contribute to the development of endometriosis.

E) CORRECT:

PID can cause fallopian tube scarring with stenosis, possibly resulting in ectopic pregnancy and/or infertility. Other complications of PID include chronic pelvic pain and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. PID is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy and infertility due to fallopian tube scarring and stenosis.
questions.hint: Intracytoplasmic inclusions on Giemsa stain of this patient's cervical discharge suggest infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient's presentation (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent cervical discharge) raises concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old man comes to your clinic with 12 hours of dull, throbbing right-sided scrotal pain. He also reports a burning sensation with urination and increased urinary frequency for the past 3 days. He has not noticed any urethral discharge. He is sexually active with one female partner and does not use condoms. On examination, his right testicle is tender, and lifting it provides relief. The penis is normal in appearance, with no discharge at the meatus. Urinalysis shows 3 WBC/hpf. Gram stain of a urethral swab reveals polymorphonuclear leukocytes but no organisms. Testicular ultrasound demonstrates increased blood flow to the right testicle compared to the left. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicocele can present with acute scrotal pain, as seen in this man, but it does not cause dysuria and leukocytes on urethral swab. Palpation of a varicocele often reveals the dilated pampiniform venous plexus. Additionally, ultrasound would clearly show the dilated hypoechoic veins, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a common cause of epididymitis in prepubertal boys, men > 35 years, and men who engage in anal intercourse. But this sexually active young man has no such risk factors. Moreover, E. coli would have likely shown up as gram-negative rods on Gram staining.

C) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the second most common cause of sexually transmitted infections like epididymitis in young sexually active males. N. gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative pathogen that would have shown up as diplococci on Gram staining. Additionally, this patient has no history of purulent urethral discharge, which is common in males with gonorrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Testicular torsion commonly presents with acute scrotal pain and swelling, as seen in this man, but Prehn's sign is typically negative and the testicle is usually high-riding, unlike in this patient. Additionally, testicular torsion does not involve dysuria, and the Doppler ultrasound would show reduced (!) perfusion to the affected testicle.

E) CORRECT:

In a sexually active postpubertal man < 35 years, the most common causes of infectious epididymitis are Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. If the Gram stain shows no organisms (especially no diplococci, which would be expected in gonorrhea), C. trachomatis should be suspected, as its cell wall does not stain. C. trachomatis can be diagnosed by nucleic acid amplification. Treatment of C. trachomatis epididymitis consists of ceftriaxone and doxycycline (see “Differential diagnosis of scrotal pain” table).

Key learning point: Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of epididymitis in sexually active men under age 35, often presenting with dysuria and sterile pyuria.
questions.hint: This sexually active young man has dysuria, a tender testicle, a positive Prehn sign (lifting the testicle relieves the pain), and increased blood flow to the testicle on ultrasonography, indicating epididymitis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She is currently sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms consistently. Her immunizations are up to date. Vital signs are normal. Physical and pelvic examinations are normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening for herpes simplex virus infections is not recommended unless the individual has a history of anogenital lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count would be required if the patient had any signs of an infection, inflammation, or anemia but is not routinely necessary in a young individual with no symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine screening for type 1 diabetes mellitus is not recommended. Screening for type 2 diabetes (e.g., with HbA1c) is not recommended until age 40 years unless certain risk factors (e.g., obesity, hypertension, family history) are present.

D) CORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is highly sensitive and specific for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae and is the gold standard for screening for these infections. Genital chlamydia and gonorrhea may be asymptomatic but can cause complications if left untreated (e.g., infertility, pelvic inflammatory disease). Since this patient is sexually active, it is recommended that she be screened for C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae, even though she is asymptomatic.

For individuals at higher risk (e.g., men who have sex with men, individuals with HIV, current or former inmates, individuals with a substance use disorder, individuals from certain Indigenous communities), opt‑out screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea every 3 months is recommended. Providers should follow the relevant provincial or local guidelines for these specific groups. All pregnant individuals should be tested at their first prenatal visit in the first trimester and rescreened during the third trimester.

Key learning point: Sexually active young individuals should have annual nucleic acid amplification testing for chlamydia and gonorrhea, with more frequent screening for those at high risk.

E) INCORRECT:

The CTFPHC recommends cervical cancer screening with a Pap smear every 3 years starting at age 25 for women who are or have been sexually active. Cervical cancer is extremely rare in women < 20 years of age. In Canada, vaccination against HPV is included in the routine immunization schedule and is delivered through publicly funded school-based programs. It should ideally be administered before any sexual contact to be most effective. Individuals aged 9–20 years receive 1 dose of the 9-valent vaccine, whereas individuals aged 21–26 years receive two doses.
questions.hint: Annual chlamydia and gonorrhea screening is recommended by the 2025 PHAC guidelines for sexually active individuals < 25 years of age (and under age 30 per the 2021 CTFPHC guidelines)

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 10-day history of dysuria. He does not report fever, chills, back pain, abdominal pain, testicular pain, or urethral discharge. He has had vaginal intercourse with multiple partners in the past 6 months without condom use. Gram stain of a urine specimen shows more than 20 white blood cells per oil immersion field, with no intracellular organisms or mobile parasites seen. Nucleic acid amplification testing is positive for Chlamydia and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is the treatment of choice for Trichomonas infection and is not recommended as first-line treatment for nongonococcal urethritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is an alternative treatment for granuloma inguinale, a genital ulcerative disease caused by the intracellular gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely causes of uncomplicated, purulent urethritis among sexually active men are Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis infection. A nucleic acid amplification test can help determine the causative organism. If chlamydial urethritis is confirmed, then the recommended treatment is doxycycline 100 mg twice daily by mouth for 7 days. Azithromycin 1 gram by mouth as a single dose is an alternative, but doxycycline is preferred because it is more effective.

Key learning point: The treatment of choice for genitourinary chlamydia is doxycycline.

D) INCORRECT:

Penicillin is the treatment of choice for syphilis. Syphilis does not typically manifest as urethritis, but coinfections are common.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice for gonorrhea.

questions.text: A 22-year-old sexually active woman presents with dysuria, urinary frequency, and postcoital bleeding for the past week. She has a new sexual partner and no prior history of sexually transmitted infections. Physical examination shows mucopurulent cervical discharge with no cervical motion tenderness. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. Vital signs are normal. Given her presentation and the need for optimal diagnostic accuracy, what is the most appropriate specimen collection method for nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT)?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Urethral swab is not routinely used for chlamydia testing in women. This collection method is more appropriate for men when urethral infection is suspected and urine collection is not feasible.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- For women, vaginal swab is the preferred specimen collection method for NAAT when testing for chlamydia. Patients may self-swab to obtain vaginal specimens.

C) INCORRECT:

While urine collection can be used to test for Chlamydia, it is not the preferred specimen collection method for women. Moreover, NAAT requires first-void urine, which contains the highest concentration of organisms.

D) INCORRECT:

First-void urine is an alternative specimen type for NAAT in women but is not the preferred method. Vaginal swab provides superior diagnostic accuracy and should be the first choice when feasible.

E) INCORRECT:

While cervical swab is an acceptable alternative specimen for NAAT in women, it is not the preferred collection method. Vaginal swab offers superior sensitivity and patient comfort compared to cervical collection. Patients may also self-swab for vaginal specimens.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with dysuria and vaginal discharge. She reports unprotected intercourse with a new partner 3 weeks ago. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Physical examination shows mucopurulent cervical discharge and cervical friability. Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis and negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. What is the most appropriate antibiotic treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for chlamydia in nonpregnant individuals but is not the first-line therapy due to increasing macrolide resistance. Azithromycin would be preferred if the patient were pregnant.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Doxycycline is the first-line antibiotic treatment for genitourinary chlamydia in nonpregnant individuals. Since the pregnancy test is negative, doxycycline is the preferred choice over azithromycin due to concerns about increasing macrolide resistance.

C) INCORRECT:

Levofloxacin is an off-label alternative treatment for chlamydia but is not the first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Amoxicillin is an alternative treatment for chlamydia specifically in pregnant individuals when azithromycin cannot be used. Amoxicillin is not indicated for nonpregnant patients if doxycycline is available.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is the treatment for gonorrhea, not chlamydia. Since the NAAT was negative for gonorrhea, ceftriaxone is not indicated as monotherapy for this patient.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks' gestation presents with dysuria and mucopurulent vaginal discharge. She has recently separated from her partner after she found he was cheating on her. She has no fever, abdominal pain, or nausea. Physical examination shows cervical friability without adnexal tenderness. Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) confirms Chlamydia trachomatis. She received azithromycin 1 g orally and tolerates it well. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform test of cure at 4 weeks and repeat testing at 3 months
Schedule routine prenatal follow-up in 4 weeks
Obtain cultures from cervix and rectum to confirm successful treatment
Initiate expedited partner therapy and discharge home
Order pelvic ultrasound to assess for fetal complications and retest for infection in the third trimester

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Pregnant patients with chlamydia require specialized follow-up including test of cure at 4 weeks and repeat testing at 3 months. This approach differs from nonpregnant patients, who typically only need repeat testing at 3 months unless there are specific concerns.

B) INCORRECT:

Routine prenatal follow-up is insufficient for pregnant patients with chlamydia. A test of cure at 4 weeks and repeat testing at 3 months are required to ensure treatment success and evaluate for reinfection.

C) INCORRECT:

Culture testing is not routinely recommended for treatment confirmation in chlamydia management.

D) INCORRECT:

While expedited partner therapy is important, pregnant patients require specific follow-up testing that differs from nonpregnant patients. A test of cure at 4 weeks is mandatory for pregnant patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasound is not indicated for routine chlamydia management in pregnant patients. The primary concerns are maternal treatment success and preventing perinatal transmission through appropriate follow-up testing. Retesting in the third trimester is an additional follow-up test that is only recommended if patients have ongoing risk factors.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with a 1-week history of vaginal discharge and postcoital bleeding. She has a new sexual partner and uses condoms inconsistently. Physical examination shows a friable cervix with mucopurulent discharge from the os. A sample of cervical cells is obtained for microscopic analysis. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed with special staining techniques?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes clue cells, which are pathognomonic for bacterial vaginosis (BV). BV is a polymicrobial infection, most notably involving Gardnerella vaginalis. It causes a thin, gray-white, malodorous vaginal discharge but does not typically cause cervical inflammation, friability, or postcoital bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

This microscopic finding is characteristic of vulvovaginal candidiasis, commonly caused by Candida albicans. Candidiasis typically manifests with intense vulvar pruritus and a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. It is a form of vaginitis, not cervicitis, and does not cause mucopurulent discharge or cervical friability.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes Trichomonas vaginalis, the causative agent of trichomoniasis. Although trichomoniasis can cause vaginal discharge and cervical inflammation (strawberry cervix), the discharge is typically described as frothy, yellow-green, and malodorous. The mucopurulent discharge and cervical friability in this patient are more characteristic of a different cause.

D) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation of mucopurulent cervicitis, cervical friability, and postcoital bleeding in a young, sexually active woman strongly suggests Chlamydia trachomatis infection. C. trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium that cannot be visualized by a standard Gram stain. During its replication cycle within host epithelial cells, it forms characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, which are aggregates of the bacteria. These can be identified using special techniques, such as Giemsa staining or direct fluorescent antibody tests. Although nucleic acid amplification testing is the modern diagnostic standard, these inclusion bodies are the classic microscopic finding of chlamydial infection.

E) INCORRECT:

This finding is pathognomonic for Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. Gonorrhea can manifest with a clinical picture of mucopurulent cervicitis that is often indistinguishable from chlamydial infection. However, N. gonorrhoeae is an extracellular bacterium that is readily identifiable on a Gram stain, unlike the organism suggested by the key microscopic finding.
questions.hint: This patient’s mucopurulent cervicitis is most likely caused by an obligate intracellular bacterium, which cannot be visualized on a standard Gram stain.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pelvic pain and vaginal discharge that began 2 days ago. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Pelvic examination shows pain with movement of the cervix and mucopurulent cervical discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge does not show any organisms. A Giemsa stain shows intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient's current condition puts her at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trophoblastic neoplasias include hydatidiform moles (complete and partial) and choriocarcinoma, which are characterized by abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue. Neither chlamydia infection nor PID is associated with the development of these conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is more strongly associated with HPV infection rather than Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Unprotected intercourse, which most likely caused PID in this patient, increases the risk of HPV infection. Cervical cancer rates are higher in women who have had PID than in the general population, but this is most likely due to increased rates of HPV infection rather than the effect of PID.

C) INCORRECT:

The etiology of endometriosis is thought to be multifactorial. Retrograde menstruation, lymphogenic and hematogenic dissemination of endometrial cells, changes in immunity and endocrine signaling, and genetic factors all play a role in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Chlamydial infection and PID are not known to contribute to the development of endometriosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilatation is associated with tertiary syphilis, which results from infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients with PID may have concomitant syphilis. However, the initial manifestations of syphilis are chancre and lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis), which are not present in this patient. Additionally, infection with Treponema pallidum does not typically cause cervical tenderness or discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Purulent arthritis is a complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While N. gonorrhoeae is a relatively common cause of PID, this pathogen is visible on Gram stain and does not show on Giemsa stain (unlike this patient's findings). A complication of Chlamydia trachomatis infection (which this patient has) is reactive arthritis, not purulent arthritis.

F) CORRECT:

PID can cause fallopian tube scarring with stenosis, possibly resulting in ectopic pregnancy and/or infertility. Other complications of PID include chronic pelvic pain and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. PID is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients.
questions.hint: Intracytoplasmic inclusions on Giemsa stain of this patient's cervical discharge suggest infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient's presentation (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent cervical discharge) raises concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
